ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Structure and properties of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ thin films by pulsed laser deposition

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Institute of Optical Communication Materials and State Key Laboratory of Luminescent Materials and Devices

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were prepared on quartz glass and α-Al2O3(001) substrates by pulsed laser deposition. The structural, morphological, and optical properties of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), atomic force microscopy (AFM), emission-scan electron microscopy (SEM), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL) measurements. The results show that the structure and properties of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were dependent on substrates. The CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films on Al2O3(0001) substrate have better crystallinity. The full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of (131) peak are 0.45 and 0.32 for the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ film on glass and Al2O3(001), respectively. The crystallite size of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films grown on glass and Al2O3(001) was about 8.22 and 9.98 nm, respectively. The oxidation state of the Sm element on the films was Sm3+ state. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured at room temperature, the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films on Al2O3(001) substrate have a better PL intensity, the identified emission bands were by the intra 4f transitions of Sm3+ from the excited level to the lower levels at 567 nm for 4G5/2→6H5/2 transition, at 609 nm for 4G5/2→6H7/2 transition, and at 657 nm for 4G5/2→6H9/2 transition.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Columbite calcium niobate (CaNb2O6) as an orthorhombic crystal structure has received a great deal of attention due to wide applications in microwave dielectrics [1, 2], photocatalyst [3, 4], laser [5], laser host material [6, 7], fiber [8, 9]. It can also be used as a low-cost lamp phosphor when doped with Eu3+ and co-doped with Ti4+ [10, 11]. CaNb2O6 exhibits very strong blue luminescence with excitation by ultraviolet radiation of 253 nm, even at room temperature [12], so it seems that CaNb2O6 can transfer its absorption energy to the activators and allow different fluorescence [13]. In present, most studies of CaNb2O6 as host material were carried out in powders and crystals. For practical application, displays with thin-film phosphors have high contrast and resolution, good heat resistance, a high degree of uniformity, superior adhesion and long-term stability. Thin-film phosphors have been prepared by a variety of deposition techniques and the pulsed laser deposition (PLD) has been used for the growth of oxide thin-film phosphors [14]. Sm3+ doped phosphors have attracted much attention because of their peculiar orange–red emission. In this study, we have investigated the growth and properties of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ thin films. To our knowledge, CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films are reported for the first time by PLD. The structure and properties of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films have been studied.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: The Sm3+ doped CaNb2O6 target was prepared by conventional solid-state reaction methods using analytical grade CaCO3, Nb2O5 and Sm2O3 powders as starting materials. These powders were weighted according to the molecular formula Ca0.98Sm0.02Nb2O6. The starting powders with designed stoichiometric quantities were ball-milled for 24 h, then dried and calcinated at 1250 °C for 10 h. The resulting powders were pressed into disk pellets and sintered at 1200 °C for 6 h. The as-prepared target showed a CaNb2O6 crystalline phase in the XRD pattern. The CaNb2O6:Sm3+ film was grown by pulsed laser deposition (PLD). The CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were deposited on quartz glass and Al2O3(0001) substrate at room temperature, oxygen pressure of 5 Pa, and laser pulse energy power of 300 mJ. After the deposition, the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were post-annealed at 700 °C for 60 min. X-ray diffraction patterns of the samples were recorded with a Rigaku D/max-IIIA X-ray diffractometer (Cu-Kα1, λ=1.5405 Å). The surface morphology of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ film was studied by AFM (Digital Instrument Nanoscope IIIa) and SEM (LEO 1530 VP). The Raman spectrum was taken with excitation of Ar+ laser at 514.5 nm. The chemical state of the films was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an ESCALAB250 system. Optical spectroscopy, including emission, excitation spectra, and the decay curves of the specimens were recorded with an Edingburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer under room temperature.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the XRD pattern of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ thin films deposited on quarts glass and α-Al2O3(0001) substrates after annealing at 700 °C. For all samples, CaNb2O6:Sm3+ thin films show polycrystalline structure on the quarts glass and α-Al2O3(0001) substrates. All the peaks including the (111), (131), and (400) of the XRD patterns for the as-annealed thin films were consistent with the orthorhombic phase of the CaNb2O6 peak. It is found that doping of Sm3+ does not cause any detectable change in the host structure. As the diffraction intensity of the film is concerned, the ones on α-Al2O3(001) substrates are obviously much higher than those on glass because of the amorphous state of the glass substrate, which indicates a better crystal quality for the CaNb2O6:Sm3+/α-Al2O3(001) films. The full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the (131) peak are 0.45 and 0.32 for the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ film on quartz glass and α-Al2O3 substrates, respectively. The crystallite size, estimated by using Scherrer’s formula of films grown on quarts glass and α-Al2O3 was about 8.22 and 9.98 nm, respectively. The grain size can be estimated from the Scherrer equation, D=0.94λ/βcosθ, where D is the average crystallite size, λ is the X-ray wavelength (0.15405 nm), and θ and β are the diffraction angle and full-width at half-maximum of an observed peak, respectively. The (131) peak in XRD for CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films deposited on α-Al2O3 substrate is sharper with small FWHM data than that on glass substrate. All of the above show that the CaNb2O6:Sm3+/α-Al2O3 film has a better crystal quality than that on the quartz glass substrate, for α-Al2O3 is a better lattice-matching substrate for growing CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films than quarts glass.
Fig. 1
XRD spectra of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films on different substrates

The optimization of chemical composition, particle size distribution, and morphology is required for the more efficient luminescence of phosphor materials. Among them, the morphology is an important factor for lower light scattering at the surface as well as higher packing densities [15]. The morphological characteristics of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were investigated by AFM and SEM. Figure 2 shows the AFM images of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films on different substrates. The CaNb2O6:Sm3+/glass film has an average grain size of about 8 nm and a root-mean-square (RMS) surface roughness of 6.912 nm, the CaNb2O6:Sm3+/α-Al2O3 film holds a grain size about 10 nm and an RMS surface roughness of 8.120 nm; and it shows that the CaNb2O6:Sm3+/α-Al2O3 film has a better crystal quality, this being consistent with the results of XRD. The small grain size of the films is one of the reasons for the relatively broad XRD peaks of the films. Figure 3 shows SEM images of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films. The thickness of the film is about 260 nm as shown in Fig. 3(a). Good adhesion of the film on the substrate was observed. It is obvious that the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ film on α-Al2O3 substrate exhibits a dense and uniform surface morphology without cracks, but that on glass is much cracked. It can be concluded that the use of different substrates may lead to different microstructure and surface morphologies of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films.
Fig. 2
AFM images of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films deposited on different substrates: (a) glass, (b) Al2O3
Fig. 3
SEM images of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films: (a) cross-sectional image, (b) glass substrate, (c) Al2O3 substrate

Figure 4 shows the Raman spectra of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films grown on glass. The spectrum presents the typical bands corresponding to the normal vibration modes of CaNb2O6 in the range of 100–1000 cm−1 [16]. The 902, 812, 602, 431 cm−1 readings are ascribed to Nb–O stretching bands; the 261 cm−1 reading is ascribed to the O–Nb–O bending vibration bands, all the Raman peaks exhibiting broadening compared to power or crystal. The peak broadening and shift of the Raman bands are related to the decrease in particle size and/or degree of order [16]. The Raman peak broadening and shift in the CaNb2O6 film may result from the decrease of symmetry in the niobate groups (an increase of disorder at the Nb2O6 sites).
Fig. 4
Raman spectra of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films on glass substrate

Figure 5 shows the XPS spectra in a wide energy range of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films. The XPS survey spectrum in Fig. 5 confirms the presence of Ca, O, Nb, Sm and C 1s (from the carbon pollution) and their corresponding binding energies.
Fig. 5
XPS spectra of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films

Figure 6(a–d) gives the spectrum of Ca 2p, Nb 3d, O 1s and Sm 3d electrons of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films, respectively. The Ca 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 6(a). The Ca 2p spectrum shows a doublet structure Ca 2p peaks (Ca 2p1/2 and Ca 2p3/2) in CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films at 350.45 and 346.9 eV. The splitting energy between the Ca 2p1/2 and Ca 2p3/2 is 3.55 eV. According to [17], this splitting energy is 3.50 eV in CaO. Figure 6(b) shows Nb 3d spectra of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films at a binding energy of 202 to 216 eV. The spectra contain two major peaks, Nb 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 at 209.95 and 207.25 eV. The splitting energy between the Nb 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 is 2.7 eV. According to [18], this splitting energy is 2.72 eV in LiNbO3. According to [19], the Nb 3d5/2 energy is 206.8, 207.0 eV in the pure CaNb2O6. The Sm 3d spectrum shows two doublet Sm 3d peaks (Sm 3d5/2 and Sm 3d3/2) in CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films at 1083.13 and 1110.4 eV (Fig. 6(c)). The splitting energy between the Sm 3d5/2 and Sm 3d3/2 core level peaks is 27.17 eV. According to [20], this splitting energy is 27.20 eV in Sm2O3. A peak at 1074.8 eV, identified as the Sm 3d5/2 peak for the Sm2+ states [21], was not observed in the samples. The results indicate that the oxidation state of the Sm element on the films was 3+. Figure 6(d) shows the fitting pattern of the O 1s XPS of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films. The O 1s spectrum has been deconvoluted into three peaks. The peak at 530.36, 531.41 and 532.6 eV, and the subpeaks are mainly ascribed to Ca–O (531.41 eV), Nb–O (530.36 eV) bonds and relaxed O phase (532.6 eV) associated with oxygen vacancies and surface species.
Fig. 6
XPS of: Ca 2p (a), Nb 3d (b), Sm 3d (c) and O 1s (d) core levels of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films

Figure 7 shows the excitation and emission spectra of CaNb2O6. Figure 7(a) shows the excitation spectra of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films monitoring the emission of Sm3+ 4G5/2–6H7/2 at 609 nm. It was found that there were two intense broad bands with a maximum at 257 and 466 nm, respectively. In the excitation spectra, a broad and strong excitation band is centered at 257 nm, ascribed to the host charge transfer transition; namely, an electron from an O ligand to the empty 4d orbital of the central Nb ions inside the [NbO6]7− groups (Nb5+–O2−) [22]. The crystal structure of CaNb2O6 was described as a layer structure built up by edge-sharing of NbO6 trigonal prisms [23]. The relatively weak excitation peaks located at 466 nm can be assigned to the transitions from the Sm3+ ground state to the high excited energy levels (6H5/2–4I13/2). Upon excitation with 257 or 466 nm irradiation, the emission spectra consist of the characteristic emissions of Sm3+ shown in Fig. 7(b). Among them, the identified emission bands were by the intra 4f transitions of Sm3+ from the excited level to the lower levels, such as 4G5/2→6H5/2 at 567 nm, 4G5/2→6H7/2 at 609 nm, and 4G5/2→6H9/2 at 657 nm. Among these, the transition 4G5/2→6H7/2 has the strongest intensity and this can be applied to the red–orange emitting display materials. As shown in Fig. 7, the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films grown on Al2O3 (0001) substrate have better PL intensity, which was higher in comparison with that of the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films grown on glass substrates. The PL performance was related to structural properties.
Fig. 7
Excitation (a) and emission (b) spectra of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films

The decay curve for the 4G5/2→6H7/2 transition of Sm3+ in CaNb2O6 films at 276 nm excitation is presented in Fig. 8. The decay curve is non-exponential or single-exponential equation. The average decay time can be calculated using the following equation [24]:
$$\tau = \frac{\int I(t)t\,dt}{\int I(t)\,dt} $$ The calculated value of the average lifetime is 0.56 ms. Applying the J–O theory [25, 26], obviously, the quenching in decay time is attributed to the Sm3+–Sm3+ ions interactions, the radiative and the experimental decay times of an emission level containing both radiative and non-radiative contributions. The non-radiative contribution might take place due to either energy transfer among the rare earth ions or multiphonon relaxation, or both.
Fig. 8
Decay curve of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were prepared on glass and Al2O3(001) by PLD. XRD, AFM and SEM measurements indicate that the CaNb2O6:Sm3+ film has a better quality on the Al2O3 substrate than that on quartz glass. The Raman peaks of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films exhibited broadening compared to power or crystal. The XPS survey spectrum confirms the presence of Ca, O, Nb, Sm, and the chemical state of the Sm element on the films was 3+. The CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films grown on Al2O3 (0001) substrate have a better PL intensity than those on quartz glass. The identified emission of Sm3+ located at 567, 609 and 657 nm radiated from 4G5/2→6H5/2, 4G5/2→6H7/2, and 4G5/2→6H9/2 transitions, respectively. The average lifetime for the 4G5/2→6H7/2 transition of Sm3+ in CaNb2O6 films at 276 nm excitation is 0.56 ms. The structure and properties of CaNb2O6:Sm3+ films were dependent on substrates.
